title: Financials Down Ahead of Trade Talks — Financials Roundup
text:
Shares of banks and other financial institutions fell as tensions appeared to rise between the U.S. and China ahead of the latest round of trade talks.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank will soon announce plans to increase the amount of short-term Treasury securities it purchases over time in order to avoid a repeat of last month's unexpected strains in wholesale funding markets. Still, Mr. Powell said the move should not be confused with prior rounds of bond-buying designed to stimulate economic growth, noting that job-market and economic conditions in the U.S. remained favorable despite some uneven data.

Robinhood Markets said it would offer a new higher-yielding cash account as it strikes back at the discount brokers who matched its commission-free trading offer. Robinhood said it would offer 2.05% annually on uninvested cash in customers' brokerage accounts, through partner banks. Exchange-traded fund providers such as BlackRock have also incurred injuries in the price war as deals they struck with discount brokers such as Charles Schwab on commission-free ETF promotions have been rendered meaningless by the dropping of all commissions, The Wall Street Journal reported.
